@Cas you are ignoring all the other, in many cases regressive taxes the so-called 47% do pay. This includes Social Security taxes, if one is self-employed that means both sides of it - and increasingly, people are "independent contractors" whether we want to be or not - so our bosses contribute zip. Also we pay sales taxes, property taxes, excise taxes, etc etc regardless of our income or our wealth.

Ergo, the system is anything but progressive.

Also, you should ask why 47% of Americans are poor. It isn't because we're lazy, believe me.

Maybe you should consider the fact that many of us are old, or we're children, or we're disabled, or we're working for virtual slave-drivers who refuse to pay a living wage.

Finally there's the fact that rich people often pay a lower percentage and sometimes, actually fewer dollars than middle class and poor people. Indeed huge corporations, with billions in profits, often pay exactly - zero.

Is that right?

Cas - For one thing, 'progressive taxation' refers to rates per income band, not revenues per band. If the top 1% of incomes do pay 39% of Federal income tax revenues, then that's yet another confirmation of our wild income inequality curve. For another thing, individuals at the top of the income distribution range are the ones with almost all of the capital gains and carried-interest income, which is indeed taxed at much lower rates than ordinary income tax. Given half a chance, they take their income in those other categories instead of as ordinary earned income. And they pay tax attorneys handsomely to avoid taxes whenever possible. Whereas people at the middle and bottom disproportionally pay other taxes, for example sales tax, and can't afford tax avoidance experts.

And all of that, to answer your question, is why what we have is most definitely not a system of progressive taxation.

@cas: The top 1% pays 39% of Federal taxes, but controls more than that proportion of the nation's wealth. Your complaint about the bottom 47% paying no taxes is justified by the fact that the bottom 50% in this country controls a mere 1% of national wealth. It is in reasonable proportion.
Most of the top 1% makes their money like Mitten$ Romney and his family, not by the sweat of his brow, but by cashing dividend checks, taxed at a mere 15%.

With continued and unabated redistribution of wealth coupled to Republican rejection of progressive taxation and revenue, it won't be for lack of money that we will fail to secure the success of Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid and reject needed investment in infrastructure, education, and economic development: rather, it will be the power of kleptocracy to dictate its will.  How will so few determine so much of the outcome?  Having fed followers a steady diet of pathological hatred for the President, Fox News and talk radio memes willfully subverting the foundations of Federal government, Tea Party obstructionism will prove as intransigent as ever: we should expect nothing better than a reprise of recent events come January and February.  Republican leadership will exercise as little control over their caucus then as they do today.  There will be no "grand bargain" beforehand and 2014 elections could change Congressional dynamics by returning control of the Senate to Republicans. All that's required is poor Democratic turnout coupled with continued voter suppression efforts.  If the Senate falls into Republican hands, kleptocrats will have all they need to effect the gradual elimination of New Deal and the Great Society accomplishments.  President Obama's veto will be the last line of defense, as the social and economic realities of a failed Confederacy become at last unavoidable.  Now give me one reason to think otherwise.  Please.

Inherent from the outset, was an underlying bigotry that sanctioned the idea that human beings could be regarded as someone else's property. The country fought a civil war over this idea and 500,000 men lost their lives. This should tell you how deeply ingrained this vision of the world was. The heir to this hideous belief is the "the Tea Party." The inconsistencies in its mantras and tactics are inconsequential when compared to their overarching goal, which is to destroy the government which has enabled minorities to gain equal footing in an egalitarian society. The election of a Black man as President deeply stoked the passions of those who were doing everything they could to suppress them. The destruction of American democracy is the only way that this segment of our society can re-establish the hegemony they seek. A few points of GDP is nothing when compared to that. Is Cruz the pied-piper that can realize their dream? Stay tuned.

"What Snowden accused the NSA of doing is what we know corporations do..."

Yes, but the NSA does it with the full force of the government of the United States of America behind it. With all the manpower, money, secrecy, and global influence and control that government has.

As powerful as corporations and teenagers in their mommy's basement may be, they can't (or at least not yet) launch a Hellfire missile off a Predator drone to kill an individual anywhere on Earth. NSA working with CIA can and has done that.

Snowden exposed the NSA's capabilities, provoking Americans to discuss what their government is doing in their name and perhaps in violation of American law. That is a really valuable service to our country.

At best Snowden seems to be saying “it’s OK my having stolen what I stole for it had been stolen by the thief from whom I stole it, and besides I hid it so it couldn’t be stolen from me by those other thieves.”

One wonders.

It’s all for the good if we debate what might the NSA be permitted to learn and know about us and how might there be oversight, but let’s not be fools. What Snowden accused the NSA of doing is what we know corporations do; what – for that matter – we imagine hacking teenagers doing from their mommy’s basements.

Recall that the US as leader of the "free" world after WWII subverted the democratic process of the United Nations in favor of a system that would give them and other members of the security council disproportionate authority in decision making. The US had the opportunity to create an enforceable security pact between all nations in the institution of the United Nations - a pact to ensure the safety of all (by ceding some degree of national sovereignty) and the US opted for an agreement that would allow it to have it both ways. If there have been 100+ wars since 1945, to what extent can we lay that failure at the feet of the US and other permanent security council members?

When Joseph Brodsky was expelled from the Soviet Union, his elderly parents spent years petitioning Soviet authorities for a permission to visit him in the U.S. The KGB response was along the lines that "such a visit will not serve a useful purpose." They never got their visa and died without ever seeing their son again.

Snowden father, of course, did not have any problems with U.S. authorities when he decided to visit his son. This, needles to say, did not even enter the picture - and rightly so. That could be the difference, in human terms, between a decent country like the U.S. (with all its warts) and "the other one." Too bad Snowden picked the wrong one.
